markdownRemark.html:
Program errors are intended to express unexpected events during the carrying out of a set of instructions. To a computer, at the lowest level, an instruction could be take these binary values (inputs), perform a logical operation, and generate a new binary value (output). In this idealised model there is not really much unexpected that could happen — other than the power socket being yanked out. Typically this level of instruction is not under consideration for day to day programming. It is too low level. Advances in the field of hardware and software have enable programmers to combine over hundreds of thousands of these lower level instructions using text with semantic value to humans. Let’s call this the text representation of our program. It is one description of the program, and it happens to the be one that programmers interact with the most.
